thread.title: North Brunswick and Piscataway high schools compete in food drive
thread.title_full: North Brunswick and Piscataway high schools compete in food drive

title: North Brunswick and Piscataway high schools compete in food drive
text:
North Brunswick and Piscataway high schools compete in food drive Greg Tufaro , @GregTufaro 8:40 a.m. EDT October 23, 2015 North Brunswick High School Principal Pete Clark after getting pied by Piscataway counterpart Jason Lester. (Photo: North Brunswick High School) 3 CONNECT 11 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
For the second time this year, North Brunswick High School sponsored a successful food drive, competing with a rival high school to generate donations for the Middlesex County Food Organization and Outreach Distribution Services. 
During North Brunswick’s homecoming football game against Piscataway on Oct. 16, students, faculty, administrators and spectators representing both high schools donated approximately 800 pounds of a variety of nonperishable foods and necessities. 
As the principal of the school that generated the most donations, Jason Lester of Piscataway got to “pie” North Brunswick counterpart Pete Clark during halftime of a game between the Greater Middlesex Conference Red Division rivals. 
Clark and North Brunswick worked with St. Joseph and its principal John Anderson on a similar challenge that took place during a basketball game between those high schools in January. The schools generated more than 1,000 cans of food for donation. 
The contributions will help replenish the county food bank’s shelves so that it can continue to provide assistance to all county residents in need. 
Approximately 80 food pantries and soup kitchens throughout the county are in the M.C.F.O.O.D.S. network, which also works in conjunction with 25 additional agencies including residential facilities, shelters, social service agencies, programs for women and children, senior citizen housing facilities and other outreach services. 
Collectively, the agencies reach a variety of people county-wide including low-income families, homeless, people with disabilities or mental and physical challenges, children and senior citizens. 
To learn more about sponsoring a food drive, visit www.mciauth.com. 3 CONNECT 11 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://mycj.co/1S0zPD7 TOP VIDEOS
